Pit_Observation.activities: Poor pit location;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: "Poor pit location" due to the location being (likely) frequently wind-loaded from south and southwest winds. Both my CT and ECT had null results. When I pulled hard on my column after my CT test there was a planar fracture at 260 cm, at the interface of the 1F layer and the P- layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
*Observing the quality of the basal snowpack, what are the facets like?
*Q: Is the basal ice layer uniform across all of Ugly Face? Up to what elevation?
*ECT - ECTX, however there was a sudden collapse of facets just below ice complex layer @ 47-48. This is where the rounding facets were observed.
*CT - Sudden planar result on the basal ice layer @ 2
Avalanche reduction efforts made throughout the winter in this area.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile dug at the site of a fatal avalanche accident. The avalanche broke in a 4F hard layer of faceted snow grains below a K- hard crust 1 cm thick. The crown depth ranged from 40 to 75 cm deep. Around the steepest part of the slope, the avalanche broke deeper into a 4F hard layer of Depth Hoar/ Faceted Grains at the ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile dug at the site of a fatal avalanche accident. The avalanche broke in a 4F hard layer of faceted snow grains below a K- hard crust 1 cm thick. The crown depth ranged from 40 to 75 cm deep. Around the steepest part of the slope, the avalanche broke deeper into a 4F hard layer of DH/ FC at the ground.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Moderate to strong wind on City Creek Peak. Wind loading on north and northwest facing slopes. Ski cut at top of peak produced one small slide not large enough to bury a human but large enough to push a skier over bad terrain. Some whumphing on a west facing slope near the pit. No other cracking or collapsing witnessed on tour.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpit dug with Ben Williams on a northwest facing aspect adjacent to an avalanche that was triggered at the same elevation. Avalanche was on a west facing slope (35 degrees) that was triggered by an animal. Wind-drifted snow avalanche 12" deep average, 30' wide and ran 200' feet. There was another smaller avalanche lower on the slope on a similar cross loaded feature. Similar Dimensions- ran about 100' downslope. Both avalanches dispersed into the brush.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Obs JC, WL.
DK, CPR, uneven rocky ground
DK, CPR, uneven rocky ground
DK, CPR, uneven rocky ground
Small knoll in the trees

Dry early winter in the eastern Beartooths has promoted significant depth hoar growth at the base of the snowpack. Since late January the NE Beartooth front has received ~65inches of snow, settled into ~85cm slab of rounds upwards to decomposing particles. Layer of concern (DH) is reactive to additional loads on the snowpack.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Variable winds. -FEW with high clouds observed. NTL in open meadows.

Location: SE, NTL, RMP, 11,200 ft Objective: To identify layers of concern in snowpack, and determine if there is potential for propagation. Results: I found failures in several weak layers, in particular a melt formation crust at about 40 cm depth. But based on several tests, preponderancy for propagation is low. Implications: Propagation in the upper 100 cm of the snowpack is low at this elevation and aspect.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Freaky Friday (Jan. 13) crust appears to be breaking down-- decomposing melt/freeze layer and some looser rounding facets sitting on top of knife crust. This was the layer of greatest concern.
